author: potuz
content: I'm not sure how little hashing takes, we're about to start benchmarking in prysm. My lasts tests showed that hashing was second right after signature verification. In any case I just got a benchmark from a machine implementing AVX512 and it was higher than 12 times faster than the current implementation (including padding block hardcoding) in the same machine, that's actually a higher gain than native sha extensions, that aren't vectorized and I've benchmarked them at x10

author: sky.cactus
content: Just to echo what Adrian said.  Benchmarking any JIT compiled language (Java, JavaScript, CLR languages, etc.) is incredibly finnicky.  The VMs often have clever optimization tricks that don't kick in right away.  For example, it may not do a certain optimization until after GC starts happening, or until enough time has passed that it can confidently identify hotpaths.
